trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to create an app with both a mobile and web client.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to create an app with both a mobile and web client.

trans-unit.source: You will create a mobile app and a web app and use the same underlying database for both.
trans-unit.target: You will create a mobile app and a web app and use the same underlying database for both.

trans-unit.source: First you will create both a new mobile app backend and a simple To do list app that stores app data in the new mobile app backend.
trans-unit.target: First you will create both a new mobile app backend and a simple To do list app that stores app data in the new mobile app backend.

trans-unit.source: The mobile app backend uses the supported .NET languages for server-side business logic.
trans-unit.target: The mobile app backend uses the supported .NET languages for server-side business logic.

trans-unit.source: The client app can use any client platform supported by Mobile App, including iOS, Windows, Xamarin iOS, and Xamarin Android.
trans-unit.target: The client app can use any client platform supported by Mobile App, including iOS, Windows, Xamarin iOS, and Xamarin Android.

trans-unit.source: Then, you will create a web app, using the same database as your mobile app.
trans-unit.target: Then, you will create a web app, using the same database as your mobile app.

trans-unit.source: At the end of the tutorial, you will have a web client and a mobile client that work with the same data.
trans-unit.target: At the end of the tutorial, you will have a web client and a mobile client that work with the same data.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Create a new mobile app backend and client
trans-unit.target: Create a new mobile app backend and client

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in the tutorial [Create a mobile app] to create both a mobile app backend and a client.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in the tutorial [Create a mobile app] to create both a mobile app backend and a client.

trans-unit.source: You can use any client platform supported by Mobile Apps, including iOS, Windows, Xamarin iOS, and Xamarin Android.
trans-unit.target: You can use any client platform supported by Mobile Apps, including iOS, Windows, Xamarin iOS, and Xamarin Android.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you have deployed your mobile app backend to Azure and that you connect your mobile client application to the hosted backend.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you have deployed your mobile app backend to Azure and that you connect your mobile client application to the hosted backend.

trans-unit.source: The mobile app code project uses Entity Framework Code First and initializes the database after the first REST request from a mobile client app.
trans-unit.target: The mobile app code project uses Entity Framework Code First and initializes the database after the first REST request from a mobile client app.

trans-unit.source: Publish a TodoList Web API from Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Publish a TodoList Web API from Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will create a new web app using a sample Web Application solution.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will create a new web app using a sample Web Application solution.

trans-unit.source: You will modify the sample to use the same database schema name and the same connection string as the mobile app.
trans-unit.target: You will modify the sample to use the same database schema name and the same connection string as the mobile app.

trans-unit.source: Before completing these steps, ensure that you've initialized your mobile app backend database by connecting a client to it.
trans-unit.target: Before completing these steps, ensure that you've initialized your mobile app backend database by connecting a client to it.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the web app will not be able to connect to the same database.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the web app will not be able to connect to the same database.

trans-unit.source: In the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>, create a new web app, using the same Resource Group and Hosting Plan as your mobile app.
trans-unit.target: In the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>, create a new web app, using the same Resource Group and Hosting Plan as your mobile app.

trans-unit.source: Download the sample solution [MultiChannelToDo] and open in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Download the sample solution [MultiChannelToDo] and open in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: The solution contains both a Web API project and a Web Application Project for the web client UI.
trans-unit.target: The solution contains both a Web API project and a Web Application Project for the web client UI.

trans-unit.source: In the Web API project, edit MultiChannelToDoContext.cs.
trans-unit.target: In the Web API project, edit MultiChannelToDoContext.cs.

trans-unit.source: In OnModelCreating, update the schema name to be the same as your mobile app name:
trans-unit.target: In OnModelCreating, update the schema name to be the same as your mobile app name:

trans-unit.source: Next we will get the mobile app connection string from the Azure Portal:
trans-unit.target: Next we will get the mobile app connection string from the Azure Portal:

trans-unit.source: Select your mobile app in the portal and click the part labeled User Code.
trans-unit.target: Select your mobile app in the portal and click the part labeled User Code.

trans-unit.source: In the blade that opens, select All Settings, then Application Settings.
trans-unit.target: In the blade that opens, select All Settings, then Application Settings.

trans-unit.source: Under Connection Strings click Show Connection Strings.
trans-unit.target: Under Connection Strings click Show Connection Strings.

trans-unit.source: Copy the value for the setting MS_TableConnectionString.
trans-unit.target: Copy the value for the setting MS_TableConnectionString.

trans-unit.source: This is the connection string used by your mobile app to connect to the SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: This is the connection string used by your mobile app to connect to the SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right click the Web API project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right click the Web API project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: Select Azure Web Apps as the publish target, and select the web app you created above.
trans-unit.target: Select Azure Web Apps as the publish target, and select the web app you created above.

trans-unit.source: Click Next until you get to the Settings section of the Publish Web wizard.
trans-unit.target: Click Next until you get to the Settings section of the Publish Web wizard.

trans-unit.source: In the Databases section, paste the mobile app connection string as the value for MultiChannelToDoContext.
trans-unit.target: In the Databases section, paste the mobile app connection string as the value for MultiChannelToDoContext.

trans-unit.source: Select only the checkbox Use this connection string at runtime.
trans-unit.target: Select only the checkbox Use this connection string at runtime.

trans-unit.source: Once your Web API has been successfully published to Azure, you will see a confirmation page.
trans-unit.target: Once your Web API has been successfully published to Azure, you will see a confirmation page.

trans-unit.source: Copy the URL for your published service.
trans-unit.target: Copy the URL for your published service.

trans-unit.source: Publish a TodoList web client UI from Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Publish a TodoList web client UI from Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will use a sample web client application implemented with AngularJS.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will use a sample web client application implemented with AngularJS.

trans-unit.source: You will then use Visual Studio to publish the project to a new hosted App Service web app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You will then use Visual Studio to publish the project to a new hosted App Service web app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the project MultiChannelToDo.Web.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the project MultiChannelToDo.Web.

trans-unit.source: Edit the file js/service/ToDoService.js, adding the URL to the Web API you just published:
trans-unit.target: Edit the file js/service/ToDoService.js, adding the URL to the Web API you just published:

trans-unit.source: Right click the project MultiChannelToDo.Web and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right click the project MultiChannelToDo.Web and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: In the Publish Web wizard, select Azure Web App as the publish target and create a new web app without a database.
trans-unit.target: In the Publish Web wizard, select Azure Web App as the publish target and create a new web app without a database.

trans-unit.source: Once your project has been sucessfully published, you will see the web UI in your browser.
trans-unit.target: Once your project has been sucessfully published, you will see the web UI in your browser.

trans-unit.source: Test the mobile and web apps
trans-unit.target: Test the mobile and web apps

trans-unit.source: In the web UI, add or edit some todo items.
trans-unit.target: In the web UI, add or edit some todo items.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View of Web Application in the Browser</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View of Web Application in the Browser</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Run the mobile app that you created in the [Create a mobile app] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Run the mobile app that you created in the [Create a mobile app] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You will see the same todo items as in the web app.
trans-unit.target: You will see the same todo items as in the web app.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View of Xamarin Mobile App</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View of Xamarin Mobile App</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: In this sample we showed how to use the same underlying database for an app that has both a website and a mobile client.
trans-unit.target: In this sample we showed how to use the same underlying database for an app that has both a website and a mobile client.

trans-unit.source: Here, we did not have any business logic in the backend that we wanted to reuse across the two clients, so it was sufficient to simply share the same database.
trans-unit.target: Here, we did not have any business logic in the backend that we wanted to reuse across the two clients, so it was sufficient to simply share the same database.

trans-unit.source: In a future tutorial, you will learn how to add business logic to your Web API and reuse that logic in your mobile app backend code.
trans-unit.target: In a future tutorial, you will learn how to add business logic to your Web API and reuse that logic in your mobile app backend code.

trans-unit.source: What's changed
trans-unit.target: What's changed

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <link><linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <link><linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <link><linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <link><linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>
